description: Continuous interviewer transcript test cases for detection accuracy testing. These simulate real interview audio streams with questions/imperatives embedded in natural speech.

testCases.description: Interview intro transitioning to first question
testCases.transcript: Okay great, thanks for joining us today. So, um, let me just pull up your resume here. Right, so I see you've been working with .NET for a few years now. What got you interested in software development in the first place?
Alright, moving on to the technical portion. What's your experience with dependency injection? And how do you typically structure your applications? Do you follow any specific architectural patterns?
Okay, that's interesting. Um, so, yeah. Tell me about a time when you had to debug a really tricky production issue. Like, walk me through your process.

testCases.description: Transitional speech with no actual questions
testCases.transcript: Right, okay. That makes sense. Let me just make a note here. So, moving on from that topic. I think we've covered the basics pretty well.

testCases.description: Setting up a coding challenge with imperative
testCases.transcript: Alright, so now we're going to do a quick coding exercise. Nothing too crazy. So, write a function that takes a list of integers and returns the two numbers that sum to a target value. You can use whatever language you're comfortable with.
So let's talk about system design. Imagine you're building a real-time chat application like Slack. How would you approach the architecture? What components would you need?
Um so like uh what would you say is your uh biggest weakness as a developer and um how are you working to improve on that

So I've been doing these interviews for about ten years now and I always find it interesting how different people approach problems. You know, some people are very methodical, others are more intuitive. Anyway, I'm curious, when you encounter a bug that you've never seen before, what's the first thing you do? Like, what's your mental model for approaching unknown problems?
Tell me about your experience working in agile teams. How do you handle disagreements with team members about technical decisions? Can you give me a specific example?
Hmm, okay. I'm not sure I fully understood that part. Can you elaborate on what you meant by eventual consistency? Like, how does that work in practice?

So we use Kubernetes here, and Docker obviously. Our deployment pipeline is pretty standard, GitHub Actions, that sort of thing. What's your experience with containerization? Have you worked with orchestration tools before?
Quick fire round. Tabs or spaces? Git rebase or merge? SQL or NoSQL? Monolith or microservices?
So you mentioned CQRS earlier. Explain how you would implement that pattern in a .NET application. What are the trade-offs?

Let's say you join a team and the codebase has zero tests, zero documentation, and the original developers have all left. What would be your approach to getting up to speed and starting to improve things?
Alright, I think that covers everything on my end. Let me check my notes here. Yeah, I think we're good. My colleague Sarah will be joining us in a moment for the next part.
